build-tools/build-img.message:
When an instance is created from an image with cloud-init installed, it seems that networking must be disabled in order to configure the default routes through user data arguments. Otherwise, cloud-init will configure its own gateways. In this change, cloud-init networking is only disabled for AWS-compatible versions of the image. A few alternatives I have in mind are:

1. Add separate option to create an image with cloud-init.
2. By default, check if cloud-init is installed and disable networking if it is.
3. Patch the cloud-init rpm before installation? That way, further modifications such as replacing the default cloud.cfg file wouldn't have to be done by the build-img script or the ks-addon.

Any thoughts?

In the case of our non-AWS QCOW2 images, we also want to be able to use cloud-init so we can configure whatever default routes we want and eliminate the IPV4-GW_ADDR and IPV6_GW_ADDR parameters in this script. I don't have an opinion on which of the three options above is best, but we definitely need cloud-init to work for the non-AWS QCOW2 images.
Is this only needed for AIO? If needed for all nodes, use --all-nodes. If only needed for controllers, you'll need args for --controller, --controller-worker, and --controller-worker-lowlatency
Thanks for your input. I will add a check for the $AUTO_MODE variable.
I don't think this level of complexity is needed. I expect you can just do --all-nodes. And if it's only for controllers, then you can specify all 3 options to the patch build command.

nfv/nfv-vim/nfv_vim/strategy/_strategy.p.message:
Is host.openstack_control always true?
on line 620 after "else:" startegy.SystemStabilizeStep() wait for only 1 minute.

The condition was there in the original code.
I wanted to change the timeout, not the logic because (1.) I am not familiar with the system and I don't understand what openstack_control implies and, (2.) the behavior is different for controller, storage, swift and worker nodes regarding openstack_control, rebooting and waiting for alarms to clear. (see second reply to Bart Wensley's comment).

The host.openstack_control indicates whether openstack is installed on the controller. Jim originally increased the timeout here because when the openstack application is installed on the controllers it takes longer for all the services to to come up after the controller is locked/unlocked.
There is a third location in this file where this step is added. I assume it should also be updated.

Thanks Andrei for the reply. Thinking about this a bit more - why is it taking 12 minutes for the ceph alarm to clear after unlocking a controller host. Does this configuration have OSDs configured on the controllers? The existing code is adding a WaitDataSync step whenever there is the expectation that there is a lot of data to synchronize (e.g. when a storage host is unlocked or when a controller or storage host has been upgraded). Why would locking/unlocking a controller cause ceph to be unhealthy for 12 minutes?

The issue arises when patching is applied but ceph is still synchronizing data between storage nodes on a system with a slow network and/or slow disks.

It is not related to ceph specifically, any non-critical alarm that does not clear within the existing timeout will fail the patching strategy.

A quick fix would be to increase the timeout and make it configurable so clients with this problem can tune their timeout to wait for slow data synchronization, if they are is this case where they perform patching while synchronizing.

Another would be to either add a new strategy o modify the existing strategy step (WaitForDataSyncStep) to explicitly look for this kind of situation.

Unfortunately, the alarm is not discriminated properly and it is lumped together with other storage/ceph alarms in id 800.001 and only the text in the alarm reason field can be used to distinguish a temporary problem (HEALTH_WARN due to nodes still synchronizing) from a failing one.

For the problem raised in our case, it would be easier to have a tunable timeout as a quick fix.

Another solution would be to leave the existing timeout for the WaitAlarmsClearStep and add the same WaitDataSyncStep afterwards on all cases (openstack_control or not) to take care of the ceph syncrhonization.
My gripes with this are that, one, I am not familiar enough with the architecture to know what such a change implies for each node type and , two, that WaitDataSyncStep is copy-pasted code from WaitAlarmsClearStep and does nothing to discriminate alarms in such a way that it looks specifically for storage/ceph related alarms ...

Well, I modified the behavior affecting the controller software update strategy.

There is a similar step in the storage node software update strategy, in SwPatchStrategy._add_storage_strategy_stages line 692, where, as I noted in the commit comments, somebody used another strategy type (WaitDataSyncStep, mostly a copy-pasted WaitAlarmsClearStep) to the same effect.

I think you are referring to the behavior in the worker software update strategy, in SwPatchStrategy._add_worker_strategy_stages, line 868.

There are two issues:
 - first I did not test this scenario, the test was with/for controller nodes.
 - second, there is the issue of code consistency:
    - different strategy types used (WaitAlarmsClearStep vs WaitDataSyncStep) which
      do the same thing.
    - hardcoded timeout values.

Then there is also the issue pointed out by another comment that the long wait is applied only on the openstack_control case.

I am not sure what this implies as I tried only to extend the timeout, give it more time for ceph to finish synchronizing so the HEALTH_WARN alarms goes away, I did not want to change the logic which will happen if I wait for all cases (to only on openstack_control).

Also, for some node types, it waits longer if it is openstack_control , while on the storage nodes the behavior is different:

 - controller nodes : if reboot required and openstack_control => WaitAlarmsClearStep
 - storage nodes : if reboot required => WaitDataSyncStep ; same thing, different class, but  
                   does not care about being openstack_control
 - swift nodes : does not wait at all (isn't swift the object storage service ?) and does not 
                 care about openstack_control
 - worker nodes : if reboot required and any locked hosts or hosts (waiting to?) reboot have 
                  openstack_control

Hello Bart,
The initial test was performed with the following (storage) configuration: 2+x+10
Yes, the issue happened when OSDs are configured on controller nodes and, unfortunately, the timeout for WaitDataSyncStep is insufficient.

I pushed another change where I added '800.001' fault to ignored alamrs list in WaitDataSyncStep, as I can only find references to it in ceph monitor and, after inspecting the code there, it seems it is only generated when OSDs are out of sync (HEALTH_WARN) not on some actual (critical) fault.

Then I added a new strategy step type WaitWhileAlarmsRaisedStep, which waits as long as the alarms in the list given to the ctor are up. I added this step at the end, after reboot, on openstack/non-openstack deployments and it is configured to wait for a longer timeout only for the '800.001' alarm.

I can't find any references to other faults for '800.001' which are actually 'management affecting' (or 'service affecting' in other parts of the code).

If there are some critical alarms which also use '800.001' then I could modify the code to look in the 'reason_text' field of the alarm which is the only way to tell if this is the specifc 'HEALTH_WARN' / 'PGs are degraded/stuck or undersized' warning.

The increase in the timeout here was to deal with a delay in services coming up after the controller was unlocked, when the openstack application is applied. The LP you are fixing here indicates that ceph is taking a long time to clear its HEALTH_WARN alarm after the controller lock/unlock (i.e. PGs are degraded/stuck or undersized). A couple questions - why is this alarm being raised for so long in this case? I'm not sure this alarm has anything to do with the openstack application being installed.

OK - so now I understand what happened. When patch orchestration was originally implemented in the VIM, OSDs could only be configured on storage hosts. When we started allowing OSDs on controller hosts, the VIM was not updated. The fix above is too complex. I think a simpler fix would be to change all the cases where a controller host is unlocked after patching to do a 30 minute WaitDataSyncStep instead of the current WaitAlarmsClearStep. I know these are essentially the same thing, but WaitDataSync will be clearer. Also add a comment similar to the comment in _add_storage_strategy_stages to indicate what we are waiting for. A future enhancement could be to make the VIM aware whether there are OSDs configured on the controller hosts, but that isn't necessary here. In the success case, where the alarms clear eventually, this change will have no impact on the patch orchestration time. In real failure cases on controller hosts without OSDs, it will increase the failure detection time from the current 10 minutes to 30 minutes, but I don't think that is going to be an issue.

nit: I think we should try to be a little more verbose when explaining the issue.  I believe the key points are:

- For backend volume replicas, it's the storage array that takes care of monitoring and replacing unhealthy replicas.
- NVMe MDRAID moves the data replication responsibility from the backend to the consumer.
- There's no mechanism to monitor and heal these replicated volumes.
- We cannot do it on the Cinder side, because even if the Cinder driver detected the issue and created a replacing volume, we have no mechanism to report the connection information of the replacing volume to the consumer.
- So the monitoring and healing needs to be on the volume consumer side.

-1: This sounds like a thread within the same process, and I don't like that approach because it has some drawbacks:

- We are using greenthreads, so any blocking on that task will affect the parent process (Nova, Cinder, Glance)
- If Nova is stopped for an upgrade (instances keep running on the hypervisor) we would lose the monitoring and healing.
- Nova is unlikely to accept os-brick running a task within its process (a different story is a different process like we do in privsep).

openstack does not strictly require sudo to work we just need a privalge escalation mechniums

but that is less commonaly used.

in anycase we shoudl avoid new uses of rootwrap and shoudl not add any direct use of sudo via process_utils.exec or similar to run arbitary commands.

The confusion here is due to the fact that all the other hooks store the operation for the app itself (apply,remove,delete,upload,update), yet this hook stores the armada operation. Thank you for pointing out the inconsistent behavior. Added a comment describing this.

The armada operation(APP_APPY_OP or APP_DELETE_OP or APP_ROLLBACK_OP) is stored in hook.operation. Here a new type of hook needed to be introduced to allow the existing retry mechanism to function. The logic operation here is an armada request, thus a new type(APP_LIFECYCLE_TYPE_ARMADA_REQUEST) of hook is introduced. Before and after a logical step are placed the `pre` and `post` hooks for that step. The app can raise ApplicationApplyFailure in this hook (post armada-request) to trigger a retry. It can check the operation field if it wants to do so only for APP_APPLY_OP.

neutron/cmd/upgrade_checks/checks.py.message:
WHen I tested the upgrade check, I hit a couple of unclear things.

(1) common_checks.check_policy_json() expects cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy_file is registered, but the code has no explicit logic to register oslo.policy options.
After I debugged which module loads neutron.policy (which registers oslo.policy options) it turned out "from neutron.db.models import agent as agent_model" at L.26 above loads neutron.policy
(The dependency tree is neutron.db.models import agent (L.26 above) -> neutron.agent.common.utils -> neutron.conf.agent.common -> neutron.common.config -> neutron.policy).
It is better to register the oslo.policy options explicitly as check_policy_json() directly requires the option.

(2) As observed in (1), the oslo.policy options are registered via neutron.policy and neutron.policy calls opts.set_defaults(cfg.CONF, 'policy.yaml') to change the default value. Thus, I expected cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy is 'policy.yaml'. Looking at the code of check_policy_json(), it just checks whether a file specified in cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy is a JSON file. The upgrade check itself complains the policy file is JSON (perhaps as you expect), but what happens? 
cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy is overridden to policy.yaml in neutron.policy, but it looks like check_policy_json() checks policy.json. Hmm???

I printed the value of cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy in two places:
- Inside of get_checks() method above -> cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy = policy.yaml
- Inside of common_checks.check_policy_json() in oslo_upgradecheck -> conf.oslo_policy.policy = /etc/neutron/policy.json

I wonder where the conf value is updated? I am confused.

updates on 1) oslo_policy.policy is registered as you mentioned via different file import but I agree to register explicitly also. done. 

RE on 2) Magic here is cli opt and how config file is loaded for those. All the CLI config option (unlike non cli config options) are registered before config file is parsed so that config file overridden value is available whole executing the CLI. In case of upgrade check tool, config file is parsed like:

1. upgradecheck call __call__ on conf object 
- https://github.com/openstack/oslo.upgradecheck/blob/c70506727800d99fbbe8133f0bf0ccb1e70d690a/oslo_upgradecheck/upgradecheck.py#L227

2. oslo.config __call__  call _parse_cli_opts() which intern load the config via _parse_config_files()
- https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/blob/cfb8c1f4a5a35ce94fa0dbc2bcf96bcfc06f231c/oslo_config/cfg.py#L2131
-https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/blob/cfb8c1f4a5a35ce94fa0dbc2bcf96bcfc06f231c/oslo_config/cfg.py#L2904

^^ this is the place where neutron.conf is loaded and value '/etc/neutron/policy.json' is loaded for cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy_file. I am sure your env have same value set for [oslo_policy]policy_file in neutron.conf


> Inside of get_checks() method above -> cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy = policy.yaml

This is default value where config file is not parsed yet so default value is shown.


> Inside of common_checks.check_policy_json() in oslo_upgradecheck -> conf.oslo_policy.policy = /etc/neutron/policy.json

This is value loaded from neutron.conf file. So upgrade checker CLI loaded the config file value correctly before common_checks.check_policy_json() is executed and it looked for correct file which is going to be use by oslo_policy for loading the rules.

So at the end this check find '/etc/neutron/policy.json as final value for conf.oslo_policy.policy_file which is correct and failed as this file is JSON formatted.

Thanks amotoki for review and testing it.

RE on 1). I expect all the neutron config option should be pre-registered for this upgrade check as you can see there are other place in this file other config option are being used like L108.

2. this checks is expected to check if cfg.CONF.oslo_policy.policy is JON formatted file or not which can be default value (now policy.yaml)or overridden by operator.

Value here and in common_checks.check_policy_json() should be same which should be policy.yaml as we are overriding the default now and no overridden value in config file. Let me debug it more if some global vs local object of CONF creating the issue here.

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/managemen.message:
I do not believe this causes the call below to GET the value from the Redfish service. If I correctly understand, it simply marks the System instance as stale. Did you mean refresh it?

    system.invalidate(force_refresh=True)

The default value of that optional argument is False. The following is more straightforward.

    system.refresh()

A more selective approach would be to only invalidate the instance when it is successfully modified. There are TODO comments in the sushy code which suggest this, including https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/7016cc0f31050ab656e1e26c80bd44ce3e9fd57a/sushy/resources/system/system.py#L260-L262.

If that were done, then system.refresh(force=False) could be called here in preparation for a read, such as by the line below. refresh(force=False) does a GET of the object only if it is invalid; otherwise, it is a no-op.

Even more selective refreshing/invalidating of System instances could be explored by overriding its base class's _do_refresh() method. Sub-resources may not need to be refreshed.
maybe allow invalidating as part of get_system() call? That is, optional invalidate param defaulting to False; in this case this would be `.get_system(task, invalidate=True)`.

Yongli He, Thank you for your explanation.

Users of a cloud system should not want or need to know anything about the underlying physical hardware; knowing anything about the underlying hardware goes against the whole idea of virtualization, IMO. Users of cloud systems should only speak or think in terms of the abstract: tiers of network performance. So, the use case here should be more along the lines of:

Alice wants certain virtual machines to have access to faster networking interfaces. She configures her virtual machine instance as normal. After launch, Alice wishes to add a new network interface to her virtual machine that has better performance than the network interface already on her VM. She calls an API to attach a new network interface, passing in some tag that indicates a better tier of performance for the interface.

Should we only allow hot unplug of macvtap devices?

It is safe, but it is not guaranteed to succeed. What happens is that  the hypervisor injects an ACPI request to unplug the device. The guest OS must co-operate by releasing the device, before the hypervisor  will  complete the action of physically removing it.  So you require a guest OS that supports ACPI unplug of course, and if the guest is crashed or being malicious there is no guarantee the unplug will succeed. Libvirt will wait a short while for success, but you must monitor for libvirt events to see if/when it finally completes.  This delayed release has implications for when Nova can mark the PCI device as unused and available for other guests to assign.

     @wrap_exception()
     @wrap_instance_fault
     def detach_interface(self, context, instance, port_id):
         """Detach an network adapter from an instance."""
         network_info = instance.info_cache.network_info
         condemned = None
         for vif in network_info:
             if vif['id'] == port_id:
                 condemned = vif
                 break
         if condemned is None:
             raise exception.PortNotFound(_("Port %s is not "
                                            "attached") % port_id)
         try:
             self.driver.detach_interface(instance, condemned)
         except exception.NovaException as ex:
             LOG.warning(_LW("Detach interface failed, port_id=%(port_id)s,"
                             " reason: %(msg)s"),
                         {'port_id': port_id, 'msg': ex}, instance=instance)
             raise exception.InterfaceDetachFailed(instance_uuid=instance.uuid)
         else:
             try:
                 self.network_api.deallocate_port_for_instance(
                     context, instance, port_id)
             except Exception as ex:
                 with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception():
                     # Since this is a cast operation, log the failure for
                     # triage.
                     LOG.warning(_LW('Failed to deallocate port %(port_id)s '
                                     'for instance. Error: %(error)s'),
                                 {'port_id': port_id, 'error': ex},
                                 instance=instance)

ironic/tests/unit/api/test_acl.py.message:
These look like token references issued from the v2.0 API? It might not matter, but I'm wondering if there is a reason for using fake v2.0 values (I think we removed it officially during rocky)?

I've been trying to stay away from mocking fake token response in the event they change (e.g., v2.0 -> v3 or v3 -> v4 if that ever happens).

Another approach would be to provide mocked or faked context objects that represent each persona:

  fake_user_id = uuid.uuid4().hex
  system_admin_context = oslo_context.RequestContext(
      user_id=fake_user_id,
      roles=['admin', 'member', 'reader'],
      system_scope='all'
  )

Another approach that would keep you from having to maintain details of keystone's API would be to use fake headers, ultimately simulating what keystonemiddleware does. The nice thing about that approach is that you can invoke oslo.context like you normally would and it provides the context object to the API in the same way it does in non-test environments.
